Message.Title: We pay women to get pregnant in Germany...
Message.Msg: Over 200 billion euros in subsidies yearly, with new subsidies to be begin soon. Unemployment less than 4% in Southern Germany, and 5-6% in Western... Wages will be squeezed higher with such low rates of unemployment, which should encourage women to get pregnant - at any rate that is what happened after World War II when the labor market faced severe labor shortages.

Message.Title: Middle East wars...
Message.Msg: So we see the Money -Lew- lecturing about matters that do not concern him. The interest rate Manipulator in Chief -Bernanke- has no doubt phoned the Bundesbank & ECB with its objections over recent policies... I imagine the next envoy will be the U.S. Secretary of war, or maybe Obama himself, begging Europe to please spend more money on war. He would no doubt be delighted if Germany put in an order for a couple hundred F-22s and started fitting out some aircraft carriers... Berlin has already announced cuts, however, and has more important matters to attend to, and the UK is cutting... So he might as well give up on that. If Obama and his team wants to engage in Imperialism on behalf of one his favored voting blocks, let the people who elected him pay for it -- they deserve it... Perhaps the Obama administration has not realized it, but the most he can hope to accomplish with such arrogance is to encourage an even stronger line against what he wants. In times past perhaps such arrogance got results, but it won't work now. He's probably figured too, or will one of these days, that if Berlin is behind something it tends to happen, and if it is against it it goes no where in the EU...

Topic.Title: We pay women to get pregnant in Germany...

Message.Msg: What inane attempt to link the labor market to pregnancies.

Topic.Title: We pay women to get pregnant in Germany...

Message.Msg: It is a fact that birth rates dropped sharply during the Great Depression in both the USA and Europe because of poor employment opportunities for men. Birth rates then rose rapidly as unemployment dropped and wages increased. Birth rates then dropped during the 1970s and early 1980s as the labor market was saturated and unemployment was elevated...The link between female fertility, employment and income is so well established in a place like East Germany it is just asinine to even discuss it. The labor market is not a homogeneous market where just any worker will do either. Jobs have very specific language, educational, and cultural requirements, and if there is a deficit of native speakers for certain positions, as there is in Germany, wages will simply rise until women produce the required babies and the state can school them. It takes time to go from pregnancy to worker, so the wage will simply rise for a long time to ratio labor until more becomes available. You should stick to things you understand - demographics is not one of them.
